references.B59HAL01USGP: Hall, R.E., and K.R. Kelson. 1959. The mammals of North America. Ronald Press Co., New York 1:1-546 + 79.
references.B83JON01NAUS: Jones, J. K., Jr., D. M. Armstrong, R. S. Hoffmann, and C. Jones. 1983. Mammals of the Northern Great Plains. University of Nebraska Press, Lincoln, Nebraska.
references.B95KUR01NAUS: Kurta, A. 1995. Mammals of the Great Lakes region. Univ. Michigan Press, Ann Arbor. xii + 376 pp.
references.B03YEN01USGP: Yensen E., and P.W. Sherman PW. 2003. Ground squirrels (Spermophilus species and Ammospermophilus species). In: Wild Mammals of North America (eds. Feldhammer G, Thompson B, Chapman J) 2nd ed., pp. 211-231. Johns Hopkins University Press, Baltimore, MD.
references.A71HAB01USGP: Haberman, C.G., and E.D. Fleharty. 1971. Energy flow in Spermophilus franklinii. Journal of Mammalogy 52:710-716.
references.R99WIL02SEGP: Wilson, D.E. and S. Ruff. 1999. The Smithsonian book of North American mammals. Washington, DC, Smithsonian Inst. Press. 750 p.

habitat_description: This ground squirrel, endemic to the north central US and Canada, prefers to create burrows on steep slopes in soft soils (Haberman and Fleharty 1971). They inhabit tall grasslands, disturbed shrublands, and woodland edges (Jones et al. 1983, Wilson and Ruff 1999) while avoiding shorter grass prairies, especially grassy areas that have been grazed or mowed (Hall and Kelson 1959, Ostroff and Finck 2003). They can be found along forest-prairie borders, edges of marshlands, and unmowed grassy borders of highways and railroads (Johnson and Choromanski-Norris 1992, Kurta 1995, Ostroff and Finck 2003). In Indiana, Johnson and Choromanski-Norris (1992) captured Franklin's ground squirrels in five times as many survey sites located within managed preserves of native tallgrass habitats as sites along roadside right-of-ways.
